# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is the Julia code that solves the problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, ' ')
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = ""
        end
        line *= " $word"
    end
    result *= "\n" * line # add the last line
    return result
end
```

This function splits the input string into words and then iterates over each word. It checks if adding a new word to the current line would exceed `text_width`. If it does, it appends the current line to the result and starts a new line. At the end of the loop, it adds the last line to the result.

Here is an example usage:
```julia
println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines", 10))
```
The output would be:
```
This function
will wrap
words into
lines
```
